TopicTitle: Any good aviation and space documenterys worth watching?

Articles.Content: Dos any one know of any good aviation and space documenters worth watching?

Well, it all depends on what you like, no idea about space, but as far a aviation goes, off the top of my head, there's the Wings Of Russia series (a rare gem, mostly war planes), Flying Heavy Metal about commercial airliners, also [http://www.zenoswarbirdvideos.com/](http://www.zenoswarbirdvideos.com/) if you're interested in WWII planes. Youtube is your friend here, lots and lots of stuff there.

> 
> Flying Heavy Metal

That title intrigues me.

BBC's "Space Race". It's a 4 part documentary-drama series about, well, the space race between Soviets and Americans. Definitely worth watching. You can find all four episodes on Youtube. There's also a brilliant Russian documentary about the development of the SU-27 Flanker called "Building the SU-27 - The best fighter jet in the world".

When we left Earth: the Nasa Missions: Documentary about the first NASA missions till the launch of Hubble.

Failure Is Not an Option(2003): A history of the U.S. manned space program from Mercury to Apollo 17, as seen by the men of Mission Control.
There's an interesting video on Youtube documenting (recreating) Yuri Gagarin's flight. It's called [First Orbit](https://youtu.be/RKs6ikmrLgg), worth watching.
Moon Machines is a pretty good mini series on the engineering that went into the Apollo program.
"Wings of the red star" is one of my favorite series. Most of them are on youtube.
Air Crash Investigation, perhaps? I found that really interesting, and - contrary to popular belief - assures me a lot on the safety of planes, and much of my aviation fascination came from it.
